heading: Welcome

Welcome companion website Organismal Biology (BIOL 115 115L) Minnesota State University Moorhead. site serves primarily beginners guide data analysis R. activity students learn use R RStudio compare phenotypic variation biological populations.
Illustration Patrice Delaney.
activities developed Chris Merkord Alison Wallace, contributions Katie Olson others.lab learn view, summarize, graph data.Parts 1 3 lab teach use R RStudio. Part 4 contains instructions assignment turn grade.Part 1 lab, learn R RStudio , RStudio environment organized, RStudio organizes work Projects. finish, create first RStudio Project, continue work rest lab.Part 2 lab, learn use Console Window run commands perform basic arithmetic operations. learn basics using functions, finally learn
creating objects using assignment operator.Part 3 lab, introduced R scripts. use Finches dataset learn
read tabular dataset R, inspect , perform basic statistical summaries . estimate means, standard deviations, standard errors mean, confidence intervals around mean. also learn plot histograms bar charts.Part 4, apply learned grass data collected Regional Science Center. create new R script, read grass data R, plot histograms plant height panicle length, estimate means variables, plot bar charts.

heading: 3.6 Functions
text: mathematical operations operator. must use known function. example, take square root:function consists name function followed parentheses, list arguments inside parentheses. functions take one argument, take , take none .commonly used function c(), combine function. combines multiple values ’s known vector:functions take vectors arguments. example, length() function returns number elements, length, vector object.Useful mathematical functions include:can even nest functions. example , c() function evaluated first, value used argument length function.Combining several features together, can calculate standard error mean (SEM) confidence interval around mean set numbers:calculated SEM can use estimate upper lower limits 95% confidence interval like :
code:
sqrt(9)#> [1] 3
k <- c(1, 2, 10, 4.7, 5.0)
k#> [1]  1.0  2.0 10.0  4.7  5.0
length(k)#> [1] 5
median(k)  # median value#> [1] 4.7
mean(k)    # mean value#> [1] 4.54
sd(k)      # standard deviation#> [1] 3.501143
length(c(1, 2, 10, 4.7, 5.0)) # nested function#> [1] 5
n <- length(k) # sample size
n#> [1] 5
sem <- sd(k) / sqrt(n) # standard error of the mean
sem#> [1] 1.565759
mean(k) + 1.96 * sem  # upper limit#> [1] 7.608887
mean(k) - 1.96 * sem  # lower limit#> [1] 1.471113
c(mean(k) + 1.96 * sem, mean(k) - 1.96 * sem)#> [1] 7.608887 1.471113

heading: 6.6 Plot a histogram
text: first step data analysis always plot data.want compare means two groups, useful plot histogram, shows often value (range values) observed.Plotting tidyverse easily accomplished using ggplot() function associated helper functions.

heading: 6.6.1 Basic histogram
text: plot basic histogram beak_length variable, use following code. Note use + ggplot() function. Copy code script run . RStudio smart enough recognize run together, putting cursor lines typing Cmd+Return run lines .can plot histograms variables changing x = part code.can also experiment different numbers bins. goal enough can see hump-shaped distribution, many many bins observations. Try plotting histogram 50 bins, another 3 bins. informational, ?
code:
# histogram ---------------------------------------------------------------

# histogram of beak length
ggplot(
  data = finches,                     # use the finches dataset
  mapping = aes(x = beak_length)      # put beak length on the x axis
) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 14)           # add the histogram, use 14 bins

heading: 6.6.2 Add facets
text: Sometimes want see distribution variable varies among different subsets data. example, answer question want see beak length varies birds survive drought. One easy way facet_wrap() function ggplot. Note add + operator geom_histogram() line.
code:
# histogram of beak length, grouped by survival
ggplot(
  data = finches,                     # use the finches dataset
  mapping = aes(x = beak_length,      # put beak length on the x axis
                fill = outcome)       # fill sets the color of the boxes
) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 14) +         # add the histogram, use 14 bins
  facet_wrap(~ outcome, ncol = 1) +   # outcome is the grouping variable
  guides(fill = "none")               # don't show a legend for fill color

heading: 6.6.3 Add labels
text: last thing might want spruce plot adding better axis labels removing redundant color legend. done labs() function :
code:
# histogram of beak length, grouped by survival, with labels
ggplot(
  data = finches,                     # use the finches dataset
  mapping = aes(x = beak_length,      # put beak length on the x axis
                fill = outcome)       # fill sets the color of the boxes
) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 14) +         # add the histogram, use 14 bins
  facet_wrap(~ outcome, ncol = 1) +   # outcome is the grouping variable
  guides(fill = "none") +             # don't show a legend for fill color
  labs(
    title = "Figure 1.",              # title
    x = "Beak Length (mm)",           # x-axis label
    y = "Number of Birds"             # y-axis label
  ) +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(size = rel(.8)))  # make title smaller

code:
# save your most recent plot
ggsave("beak_length_histogram.png",   # you choose a name for the file
       width = 3.5, height = 3.5,     # dimensions of saved file DO NOT CHANGE
       units = "in")                  # units for the dimensions DO NOT CHANGE

heading: 6.7.1 Summarize by group
text: following code summarize dataset calculating mean, standard deviation standard error mean (SEM) beak_length variable.Notice use equations learned Part 2.group_by(outcome) function tells R give us separate summaries outcome (died vs. survived).number 1.96 code derived statistical theory. need change analyses later.
code:
# summarize ---------------------------------------------------------------

# summarize the dataset by outcome (survived vs. died)
beak_length_grouped_summary <- 
  finches %>% 
  group_by(outcome) %>% 
  summarize(
    mean = mean(beak_length),
    sample_size = n(),
    standard_error = sd(beak_length) / sqrt(sample_size),
    upper_conf_limit = mean + 1.96 * standard_error,
    lower_conf_limit = mean - 1.96 * standard_error
  ) %>% 
  print()                             # print the results in the console#> # A tibble: 2 × 6
#>   outcome   mean sample_size standard_error upper_conf_limit lower_conf_limit
#>   <chr>    <dbl>       <int>          <dbl>            <dbl>            <dbl>
#> 1 died      10.5          50         0.0987             10.7             10.3
#> 2 survived  11.1          50         0.119              11.3             10.8

heading: 6.7.2 Plot summarized data
text: plot means confidence intervals, can use bar chart geom_col() geom_errorbar() functions ggplot:good figure legend figure :Export figure:
code:
# bar chart ---------------------------------------------------------------

# bar chart of mean beak lengths
ggplot(
  data = beak_length_grouped_summary,   # dont use the original finches dataset
  mapping = aes(x = outcome,            # survival on the x axis
                y = mean,               # mean beak length on the y axis
                fill = outcome)         # make died/survived different colors
) +
  geom_col() +                                 # add columns
  geom_errorbar(                               # add error bars
    mapping = aes(ymin = lower_conf_limit,     #   lower 95% confidence limit
                  ymax = upper_conf_limit),    #   upper 95% confidence limit
    width = .3                                 #   width of horizontal bars
  ) +
  guides(fill = "none") +                      # don't show fill color legend
  labs(
    title = "Figure 2.",                       # title
    x = "Outcome",                             # x-axis label
    y = "Beak Length (mm)"                     # y-axis label
  ) +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(size = rel(.8)))  # make title smaller
# save the beak length bar chart
# note that the dimensions are different from the histograms above
ggsave("beak_length_bar_chart.png", 
       width = 2.5, height = 3.5, units = "in")  # DO NOT CHANGE

heading: 6.7.3 Compare means
text: visualized different samples, looks like difference means.question ask : observed difference great real difference populations. happen individuals shorter beaks one group simply due act random samping? answer question, need statistical hypothesis test.

heading: 6.7.3.1 Conduct a t-test
text: t-test statistical test tell difference means two groups likely due chance (.e. sampling error) .t-test function R t.test() can used like :first part code , beak_length ~ outcome, tells R compare mean beak lengths among two outcomes (died survived).second part, data = finches, tells R use finches dataset.
code:
# t-test ------------------------------------------------------------------

# perform a two-sample t-test assuming unequal variances
t.test(beak_length ~ outcome, data = finches)#> 
#>  Welch Two Sample t-test
#> 
#> data:  beak_length by outcome
#> t = -3.6335, df = 94.807, p-value = 0.0004539
#> alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0
#> 95 percent confidence interval:
#>  -0.8681443 -0.2546557
#> sample estimates:
#>     mean in group died mean in group survived 
#>                10.5122                11.0736

heading: 6.7.3.2 Interpret the Results
text: two numbers focus p-value 95% confidence interval.p-value tells proportion time expect find difference population like two fact . Scientists generally use cutoff (alpha level) 0.05 determine difference “statistically significant”. case, p-value 0.0004539 much lower 0.05, can reject null hypothesis accept alternative hypothesis true difference means equal 0.evidence difference means equal zero, can see 95% confidence interval include zero.report findings t-test, example Results section report scientific article, say:

heading: 9.1 Introduction

heading: 9.7.1 A new variation
text: Finch Selection Example Intraspecific Variation Analysis, created histogram group also colored histograms differently group.theory, reason can’t use different variable color histograms.example, finch data colored sex:current assignment, put generation plants panel, set fill color columns whether plants selected breeding .Remove line guides(fill = "none") + show fill color legend.figures, use subtitles set titles say "Figure 1." "Figure 2.".example:
code:
# histogram of beak length, grouped by survival, colored by sex
ggplot(
  data = finches,
  mapping = aes(x = beak_length,
                fill = sex)           # color the boxes by gender
) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 14) +
  facet_wrap(~ outcome, ncol = 1) +   # put each outcome in its own panel
  labs(
    title = "Distribution of beak lengths",
    subtitle = "Grouped by sex and outcome",
    x = "Beak Length (mm)",
    y = "Number of Birds"
  )

heading: 10 Beak Length Script
text: code used analyze beak length finches dataset.can either copy code paste new R script, e.g. plant_height.R, download R script, copy, paste .’ve copied code, can work changing file paths, object names, column names, axis labels needed perform Intraspecific Variation Analysis.
code:
# load packages -----------------------------------------------------------

# run every time you restart RStudio
library(readxl)     # load readxl, for reading Excel files
library(tidyverse)  # load tidyverse, for working with datasets


# read data ---------------------------------------------------------------

# read the finches data
finches <- read_excel("finches_data.xlsx")

# print the finches tibble in the console
finches

# take a quick look at all the variables in the dataset
glimpse(finches)


# histogram ---------------------------------------------------------------

# histogram of beak length, grouped by survival, with labels
ggplot(
  data = finches,                     # use the finches dataset
  mapping = aes(x = beak_length,      # put beak length on the x axis
                fill = outcome)       # fill sets the color of the boxes
) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 14) +         # add the histogram, use 14 bins
  facet_wrap(~ outcome, ncol = 1) +   # outcome is the grouping variable
  guides(fill = "none") +             # don't show a legend for fill color
  labs(
    title = "Figure 1.",              # title
    x = "Beak Length (mm)",           # x-axis label
    y = "Number of Birds"             # y-axis label
  ) +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(size = rel(.8)))  # make title smaller

# save your most recent plot
ggsave("beak_length_histogram.png",   # you choose a name for the file
       width = 3.5, height = 3.5,     # dimensions of saved file
       units = "in")                  # units for the dimensions


# summarize ---------------------------------------------------------------

# summarize the dataset by outcome (survived vs. died)
beak_length_grouped_summary <- 
  finches %>% 
  group_by(outcome) %>% 
  summarize(
    mean = mean(beak_length),
    sample_size = n(),
    standard_error = sd(beak_length) / sqrt(sample_size),
    upper_conf_limit = mean + 1.96 * standard_error,
    lower_conf_limit = mean - 1.96 * standard_error
  ) %>% 
  print()                             # print the results in the console


# bar chart ---------------------------------------------------------------

# bar chart of mean beak lengths
ggplot(
  data = beak_length_grouped_summary,   # dont use the original finches dataset
  mapping = aes(x = outcome,            # survival on the x axis
                y = mean,               # mean beak length on the y axis
                fill = outcome)         # make died/survived different colors
) +
  geom_col() +                                 # add columns
  geom_errorbar(                               # add error bars
    mapping = aes(ymin = lower_conf_limit,     #   lower 95% confidence limit
                  ymax = upper_conf_limit),    #   upper 95% confidence limit
    width = .3                                 #   width of horizontal bars
  ) +
  guides(fill = "none") +                      # don't show fill color legend
  labs(
    title = "Figure 2.",                       # title
    x = "Outcome",                             # x-axis label
    y = "Beak Length (mm)"                     # y-axis label
  ) +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(size = rel(.8)))  # make title smaller

# save the beak length bar chart
# note that the dimensions are different from the histograms above
ggsave("beak_length_bar_chart.png", 
       width = 2.5, height = 3.5, units = "in")


# t-test ------------------------------------------------------------------

# perform a two-sample t-test assuming unequal variances
t.test(beak_length ~ outcome, data = finches)
